utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Damn it, Zach. This is the last time I’m turning around. The next time you forget something, you're gonna be on your own.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: I can't play without a stick.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Then I guess you won't play.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: I don't care. I suck anyway.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Don’t say that.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: I’m the worst guy on the whole team.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: No, you're not.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: Then who's worse?

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Don’t worry about anyone else. Just do your best.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: See? You can't name anyone.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Zach, stop it.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: Then name someone. You can't, can you?

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Donny… Mark… Navid.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: You really think I’m better than those guys?

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Yes. Hurry up and get your stick.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Zach, get back in the car. I need an ambulance at 860 Oakwood Avenue!

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: Why is dad's car on?

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Get back in the car, Zach! Come on. Come on! Oh, come on. Don’t do this to me, Jeff! Don’t do this!

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I just… I couldn't take the pain anymore.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Either I need a new watch, or Mowgli is cutting into your Beauty Sleep.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I was up all night looking at finance reports, and Rachel is doing great. Thanks for asking.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Proving that you're a better foster mom than a homeless drug addict.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Departmental budgets are due this week.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m gonna need an extension. Got some time next decade.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Cameron already turned yours in.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s nice of her. Two questions — Why did she? And why are you telling me?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Same answer — now you owe her a favor.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m gonna need an extension. I got some time —-

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House, I’ve got a DYFS home visit on Friday.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And I’ve got a w-h-o-r-e visit on —-

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Mama’s busy. You two are gonna have to go play outside for a while.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: 32-year-old male with chronic pain all over.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: This is the favor? I was expecting something involving whipped cream and tongue depressors.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: He’s seen seven different specialists over three years. No diagnosis and no relief.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, I am fascinated already. It’s like I’m treating myself. He gets cured, and I get to learn a valuable lesson about the milk of human kindness.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: If I thought you learned lessons, I never would've quit.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So you're wasting a favor because?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I think you can help this guy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Drug-seeking patients —

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Don’t attempt suicide with medicine cabinets full of narcotics.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Sounds like fibromyalgia.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Sounds like you don't work for House. A diagnosis that provides neither an explanation nor a cure is by definition not a diagnosis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The American College of Rheumatology would disagree. There are specific diagnostic criteria.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Which this guy doesn't meet. Putting pressure on his pain helps, doesn't make it worse. He’s got abdominal pain, severe headaches, muscle cramps that come and go.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: And he tried to off himself. He’s obviously mentally ill. Pain’s probably psychological.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: It is not a sign of mental illness to want to be pain-free.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It is if your solution is sucking on a tailpipe. Sane people don't attempt suicide.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Not ever? So if you were being burnt at the stake… And someone handed you a gun…

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I’d shoot the guys with the torches. Not one doctor this guy has seen in the past three years has been able to find a single thing wrong with him. What does that tell you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It means they're idiots. It means we got to start from the beginning. We’ll do a pain profile to rule out psychosomatic pain. Search the home. Go home. Get a refill… And a doughnut.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I’ll help with the home.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Choose a statement in each group that best describes how you've been feeling lately, including today.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I’m not depressed. I know what I did was stupid.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I usually sleep well. I have some trouble with sleep. I have a lot of trouble with sleep.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I have a lot of trouble.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: It’s up and down. Between the pain and the meds, his sleep pattern's pretty erratic.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He’s a calm person. He’s more nervous than most people. He’s so nervous, he's miserable.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: He’s definitely calm. Sometimes calmer the worse the pain gets. I think talking, interacting with other people actually makes it worse.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Interesting.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Why? Does that mean something?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No, it's just we've seen that in other… patients.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He can do chores around the house. With help, he can do chores. He no longer can do chores.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: He helps all the time. He’s really strong. He used to play hockey. And he was really good too.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I believe there's hope. Hoping for things to get better is a struggle for me. Most of the time, I feel completely hopeless.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: He still laughs… All the time.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: He was always optimistic. He still is. It’s just… it's harder now.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I guess… I pray for strength more than hope.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: There’s nothing in there but a pharmacy's worth of pain meds. This guy makes House look like a Christian Scientist. He’s also more compliant than House. Kept all the inserts, had daily pill dispensers to make sure he didn't mix them up. I guess if you're gonna go out in a car, this ain't a bad one to choose.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: If I ever did it, definitely wouldn't be like that. Don’t worry. I’m not making any plans.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I certainly wouldn't know. Ever since we kissed, you've been avoiding me.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No, I haven't. Just been busy. Metal polish could cause nerve damage if he inhaled enough of it. Judging by the shine on that car, he used a fair amount.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Judging by the fact that he owns a body shop and one of these, I’d say he knew not to inhale. Busy tonight? We can get some dinner.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I don't think so.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: So making out, okay. Meals, too intimate?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I don't want to kiss you again either.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why? Because we work together?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No. Because I like you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That makes a lot of sense.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: What doesn't make sense is me getting involved with anyone.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I thought you'd gotten past that. That’s why you agreed to the drug trial. You can't give up on life because —

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I’m not giving up on life. I’m just giving up on you. I finally feel like I have a grip on things. I can handle this. What I can't handle is dragging anyone else down with me. Does this look like quail to you?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: You think he's had food poisoning every day for the last three years?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Wild quail can be toxic, cause rhabdomyolysis, which would explain his pain, as well as the elevated CK levels.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So would the carbon monoxide he sucked out of his car. It’s not a toxic reaction. It’s a psychosomatic reaction. The pain profile showed an excessive concern about his physical health, difficulty sleeping, getting out of bed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s not in pain because he's depressed. He’s depressed because he's in pain.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Not according to the pain profile you ordered. It’s not a diet issue. We should start him on antidepressants for his sake, as well as his family's.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’re not diagnosing his family.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We’re not diagnosing you either.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s rhabdo. Push IV fluids, check his urine, do a muscle biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What muscle? He says it hurts all over.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then she'll biopsy all over.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If Cuddy can come in late, I can leave early. If you need anything while I’m gone, just ask Cameron to do it.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: So if he just stops eating quail, the pain will go away?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: If we're right, it's definitely treatable.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: My arm! It’s starting to —

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: He needs more medicine.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: BP is down. We need to get him in Trendelenburg position.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Jeff, can you hear me?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: He’s arresting.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We need a crash cart in here!

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He’s not answering his cell either.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: VQ scan showed a pulmonary embolism.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Means the pain's not psychosomatic.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It also means it's not rhabdomyolysis.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Up till now, his heart and lungs were the only places he didn't have pain.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Means it's getting worse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Got to let the phone ring more than four times when you're calling a cripple. Chronic pain and pulmonary embolism, go.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: How’d you know he had —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You called after midnight. It’s got to a heart problem. Heart only would be consistent with rhabdo, which means Thirteen and Foreman would be singing in the rain, which means it has to be lungs as well.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Hypercoagulable state could cause pain and a PE.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You think the blood clot was caused by a clotting problem. That’s helpful.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: What if it's a cancer syndrome, like Trousseau's? Explains blood clots, multifocal pain, lack of obvious physical signs.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And why he's gone three years without anyone seeing it. Check his chest, abdomen, and pelvis for tumors.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Why did he think only you two would be singing in the rain?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Bone windows are normal.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Checking for cancerous masses in the lungs. So, uh, who do you know who committed suicide?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Hemingway, Goebbels, Romeo and Juliet.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Your mom? Dad?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Saying I wouldn't do it under any circumstances means my whole family was suicidal?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Nope, but categorically insisting there are no circumstances means you've got baggage — Personal betrayal, abandonment.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Just because you grew up in a Charles Dickens novel…

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Well, it's people like me who don't do it. When your life sucks from the beginning, there's nowhere to go but up.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Thorax is clear. No tumors in the lungs. The only betrayal comes from father of the year in there. He has a wife, a kid — People who count on him to have a pulse.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Okay. Switching to high-res cuts of the abdomen.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: My parents live very happily in Queens. They never attempted, thought about, or attempted to think about committ — What?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: There, along his diaphragm.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: That’s not cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No hurry. I already bathed once this week. I wouldn't want to look elitist.

utterance.speaker: Plumber
utterance.content: Can’t do anything till I write up an estimate.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fine. Pad it all you want. Here’s a check for the deductible. Don’t touch the piano and lock up when you leave.

utterance.speaker: Plumber
utterance.content: Sorry, deductible doesn't apply here.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, I’m no architect, but I’m pretty sure the master bedroom is part of the home, which means the home warranty —

utterance.speaker: Plumber
utterance.content: Doesn’t cover negligence. This pipe goes through the ceiling, over that wall, and into your shower. It didn't burst. It was pulled apart.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, 'cause I’m clearly a guy who likes to knock out a few naked pull-ups before I greet the day.

utterance.speaker: Plumber
utterance.content: You hang laundry in there?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m about to hang a plumber in there.

utterance.speaker: Plumber
utterance.content: Look, there's no rust. There’s no corrosion. I don't know how it happened, but I know what happened, and it's not covered.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So…

utterance.speaker: Plumber
utterance.content: Whenever you're ready to spend the $2,200… Give somebody else a call.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I promise, I’m only holding your hand to check for choreiform movement. I’m getting absolutely no intimacy from it.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I told you, it has nothing to do with you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I know. That’s the problem. There’s 80 reasons we shouldn't date, but you can't shut everyone out. You’re gonna need help, support.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Look at our patient. 32 years old, not dead yet, and already he's traumatized his wife, his son —

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And I’ll bet they're cherishing every traumatic minute he has left, wouldn’t trade him for the healthiest guy in the world.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: True. And they're stuck suffering with him, hating every day. Only their pain has no prospect of relief.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: This a bad time?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: No trace of cancer in the patient.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: But we did find edema in his intestines, air in the intestinal blood vessels, and House won't answer his phone.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His intestine must be damaged. The air's leaking into his body.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: If there's a blockage in the superior mesenteric artery, it could be choking off blood flow to his intestine.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Blockages all over his body would explain his pain, why the cramps come and go.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Do an angioplasty on the superior mesenteric and find the other blockages before he has another cardiac arrest.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I’ll help.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good thing we don't have a suicidal patient with a horrific, undiagnosed pain disorder.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We did till we diagnosed it. We found intestinal edema and air in the blood vessels. Pain was vascular.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If it was vascular, we would've seen uneven pulses.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: His blood pressure was uneven. Thirteen and Kutner are doing an angio.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He had hemorrhages in his fingers.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: There’s air in the intestine. It has to have come from somewhere.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes, it does.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: After we thread the catheter through his groin and into position, the blood will start flowing freely again.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: Will that take away the pain?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It will be completely ineffective, and the pain will completely go away. Cancel the angio.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: He has air in his blood vessels. If we don't open the artery to his intestines —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where can air come from? Hmmm. Air can either come from a breach in the lumen in the small intestine, or in rare instances, air can come from the air. Teeth marks. I’m guessing from when he blew into his IV tube.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Air bubble caused the PE and cardiac arrest.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You tried to finish the job that you started at home.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Jeff… Why? You said that you never —

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I lied. I wanna die. Please just let me die.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: He’s in a hyperbaric chamber. A dose of high pressure ought to chase the air out of his blood.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Is anyone keeping an eye on him, because this whole idea of suicidal watch was specifically created for suicidal patients. I realize how you might've thought the name was just a coincidence.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are there any visuals in this room that are key to us learning our lesson? 'Cause the telephone —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m inconveniencing you because you inconvenienced me. When was the last time you showered?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Scent of a man! I realize you haven't experienced it sober.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Anyone should be able to handle a depressed pain patient…

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He insisted he was no longer —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Apparently he lied. Didn’t think I’d have to remind you of that remote possibility. I have a DYFS inspection in less than 24 hours, so if you can't control —

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Non-motor seizures. Sorry, I was thinking about the patient. What were you saying?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Go on.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The pain started in his abdomen near his intestine. The first symptom has got to be key.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s had multiple EEGs, all of them cleaner and squeakier than Cuddy's rubber nipples.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What about a glycogen storage disease like McArdle's? It explains the pain. Plus there's plenty of muscle cells in the wall of the intestine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Fourteen is right. Go run an ischemic forearm test.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Take the garbage out on your way out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you want a man to take your crap, you have to marry him first.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Or employ him. Good girl.

utterance.speaker: Janice
utterance.content: I don't think I’m ready to run a decathlon yet.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Ah, if we can get you managing your life a bit better, that'll be plenty. Dr. Hadley, whenever you're ready.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Janice. You look better.

utterance.speaker: Janice
utterance.content: Yeah, they said my basal ganglian volume’s improved. All I know is for the first time in two years, I can drink a cup of water without spilling it all over myself. Thank you for getting me back in the study.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I haven't even seen you in weeks. I didn't even know our appointments were back-to-back again.

utterance.speaker: Janice
utterance.content: Well, they weren't. Mine got switched this morning.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We’re gonna take your blood repeatedly. If the increased strain makes your arm hurt more, you have a muscle abnormality.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: If you're right about this McArdle’s disease, can you take away the pain?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: With gene-replacement therapy, with lifestyle changes, we can reduce it.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Keep squeezing the ball.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: How long does he have to —

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Maybe you and Zach should get something to eat.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Honey, don't worry about us.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I’m not. Please get out of here. These tests are all I can handle.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: They’re trying to help you.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: They can't.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Then how about helping them, you know, by not being —

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: An ass? You have no idea what I’m going through.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I know it's better than what you tried to go through.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Sure, no baggage at all. Where’s the pain worst right now?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Left arm.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Does it hurt more?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Couldn’t.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: And lactate level is steady. It’s not any kind of glycogen.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Ahhhh! Oh, God! Pain jumped to my leg! That’s never happened before.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Chest, your abdomen — you feel anything there?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: No! My leg! It feels like it's being sawed off.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Nice.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Switching Janice’s appointment time so I could see the skies brighten like a lifetime TV movie.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don't know what you're —

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Sticking your most improved study participant in my face. Is that your way of getting into my pants?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I don't make the schedule, and if I did, I wouldn't use it as a social lubricant. And this is the first I’ve heard of Janice improving at all. So, hey, thanks for the good news.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Pain started in his abdomen. Now it's hopped from his left thumb to his left leg, skipping the trunk entirely.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need the name of a good lawyer.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We're getting sued?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Probably. That’s Cuddy's problem.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Hopping pain, means it's something in his brain, not his body.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Except the pain's in two places that connect to two separate regions of the brain. Which means you're not using yours. Come on, you're from one of the 12 tribes. You know must know a ton of shysters.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What type of lawyer do you need? I’ll bring it up at the next world domination subcommittee meeting.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Didn’t say I needed a lawyer. I said I needed the name of a lawyer.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Pain hopped to another limb on the same side. It’s got to be central —

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Could still be peripheral. If multiple areas of disc disease —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Were consistent with a completely spotless MRI. Who represented the hospital when you set that patient on fire?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Chris Carrick.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Chris? That doesn't sound like a very good lawyer.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: If we can't even resolve body versus brain, we're never gonna diagnose the guy.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What was the name of the firm?

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Caddell and Carrick. It’s not like we can chop off his head to see if the pain goes away.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Need to cut off a guy's head. Got to figure out if his pain's coming from his brain or his body. A stiff shot of lidocaine below the brain stem should numb him all the way down to his tippy toes.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And hearing me say "no" over the phone wasn't good enough?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m inconveniencing you because you inconvenienced me.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You know that foster-care official is coming in the morning.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If they weren't, there'd be no inconvenience.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Do not try and force me to choose between my child —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m forcing you to do your job! If you can't also —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fine, you want to separate a patient's central nervous system from the rest of his body.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If the pain stays, it's in his brain. If it vanishes —

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: And what about options three, four, and five? His respiratory system freezes, or he dies of infection, or he leaks CNS fluid like a fire hydrant, which would make him wish he were dead?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You need to scratch option five. He’s already there.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You preach objectivity, but as soon as a patient comes in in pain, all you want to do is look under the hood. You don't care if there's a one-in-three chance you'll kill him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If I don't diagnose him, there's a one-in-one chance he'll kill himself.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I gotta go. Do whatever it is you think is right.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Tammy, you said you were gonna be a little late. DYFS is gonna be here in an hour, and this place is a disaster. Never mind.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: This should numb everything from your shoulders down. Any pain that's peripheral should be gone. What are you doing here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Just stretching my leg. Carry on.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Bad pain day today?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: About to get better. Don’t worry. He’s making yours a double.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: I remember when the drugs still made things tolerable. I still thought I had good days left.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Turns out you have to live to find out.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: You don't have a family, do you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Left them all back on Krypton.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: You’re alone. That’s why you can handle your pain. No need to put up a front, to be what anyone else wants you to be. You’re having more bad days lately, aren't you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Take a look at your future. Let’s hope the drugs work this time.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I really wasn't expecting you till later.

utterance.speaker: Carlton
utterance.content: Had a cancellation, so I thought I’d knock you off the docket.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Well, I’m sorry this place is such a mess. It’s been a bit of a difficult workweek.

utterance.speaker: Carlton
utterance.content: Any guns in the house?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Uh, no.

utterance.speaker: Carlton
utterance.content: Pets? Besides the ants?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Carlton
utterance.content: Nice bag. Pricey way to ditch the diapers.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That’s not what I usually — Um, I sort of panicked. Mr. Carlton, if you'd just give me a minute to explain.

utterance.speaker: Carlton
utterance.content: Everything looks fine.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Really?

utterance.speaker: Carlton
utterance.content: Dr. Cuddy, you've got sufficient income, a high degree of personal and professional stability, and you care enough to be embarrassed by what a mess this place is. Believe me, that puts you head and shoulders above most of the foster moms I visit. See you next year, if you haven't adopted her by then.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: My legs… They’re different. Better.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No pain at all?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: No, but less. Four out of ten, maybe five.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can’t be. If whatever is causing the pain is in your brain, it's still a ten. Periphery is zero.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: It is? Some of the pain is gone, but not all of it. What does this mean?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Maybe Taub was right. It’s psychosomatic after all.

utterance.speaker: Carrick
utterance.content: Which one of you is House?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: The big black guy.

utterance.speaker: Carrick
utterance.content: Chris Carrick. Next time you use my name in a threatening e-mail, it won't be just a bill. It’ll be a lawsuit.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can you blame me? The last time that happened, the guy shot me.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: What if the spinal block triggered some sort of placebo effect?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Guy’s taken the finest opiates Blue Cross can buy. How come they didn't trigger a placebo effect?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: What happened?!

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: He just started screaming, do something! Please, God, do not let it be what his father has.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think he's faking.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: How dare you?! What makes you think —

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House, the kid's in excruciating —

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Where is he going?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where is it?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Where’s what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: His idiot son distracted the orderlies so that daddy death wish here could down a bottle of isopropyl. Get him on dialysis, or in half an hour, he'll be a corpse.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: You’re hurting me.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Remember the feeling. Maybe next time you want to help pops, you'll do a better acting job.

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: You can't help him.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Zach, why did you do this?

utterance.speaker: Zach
utterance.content: Because he's not dad anymore. He just wants it to be over with. Please. Please, just — just let him die.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Fabry disease might be able to cause central and peripheral pain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No angiokeratomata.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Lightning pain from syphilis.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: All the syph tests were negative. Why aren't you guys still talking?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Because we ran out of ideas.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Nothing explains this.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Something has to.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Unless… Nothing does.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: So now you think —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Mine’s a more interesting version of nothing. It used to be something. We can't find anything because whatever injury caused the original pain healed a long time ago. The only thing left is the drugs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Opioid induced pain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Pain and the drugs that treat pain work by changing brain chemistry, sometimes to the point where pain receptors read painkillers as killer pain. Take him off the drugs.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We can't cure him, so we're gonna torture him?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Torture is the cure. Eventually his body will recalibrate itself.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Assuming you're right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes. I find it confusing to assume otherwise.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: How would you like to stop taking Vicodin?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good thing I’m not the patient.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s open. Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Is it too big?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: She’ll grow into it. You can put it there.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I take it the home inspection was pushed back.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I passed.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You do realize that's a good thing?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: This place was a disaster. I had to stash a dirty diaper in my briefcase.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: So you buy another briefcase.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I let House supervise himself. That’s like handing a 12-year-old the keys to the liquor cabinet and the car.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You passed the inspection. The patient lived. The car is still in the driveway. And the next time my nanny gets sick when House wants to saw someone in half?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Did I mention you passed the inspection?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I passed by their meager standard. I failed by mine.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why do women always do that?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Fail?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Create ridiculous standards that no human could meet, with your careers, with your kids. You got to be more like us men.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Be lazy? Blame others?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Get help! Most men in your position have a deputy and two assistants at work, and a wife and two nannies at home. You’re not superwoman. Don’t be a martyr.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: We’ll be injecting you with naloxone, which will knock the opioids out of your pain receptors. If we're right, your system will recalibrate within a few hours, and most of the pain will be gone.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Hours? I need those drugs.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Not if they're causing your pain.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Then knock me out, sedate me while you —

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: That takes drugs too. We need to clear everything out of your system.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Please, I’ll try anything else.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: That’s what we're trying to stop.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: So it's not your parents. Then it's your wife, someone you were close —

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Colleague. We were residents together. I should've done more to stop it. He had the mother of all god complexes. So busy treating everyone's problems, he was blind to his own. Helped himself to a vial of insulin. It’s a miracle he survived. His friends and family almost didn't. He was a selfish ass.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: It’ll be over soon.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: This is lunacy. You’re torturing this guy on a hunch.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s the only hunch we've got. If I really wanted to torture him, I’d manipulate a clinical trial in the hopes that he'd sleep with you.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Are you suggesting I got Thirteen in that trial because of some personal —

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think you got her in because of your usual Messiah complex. I think you messed with the appointment schedule because of your "I like to have sex" complex. I checked the logs. You moved your most promising patient right before her. False hope being quite the aphrodisiac.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: How’s it false if the trials are showing results?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, if it were that promising, you wouldn't have to change the schedule. But, hey… Hope springs eternal.

utterance.speaker: Fernando
utterance.content: This was a cooking accident?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: First time making cherries jubilee.

utterance.speaker: Fernando
utterance.content: Awfully big fire.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If you ask me, some of the portions in that recipe were off. Sure hope it happens to be covered under, say, section three, subsection 2.2, paragraph one, accidental fire damage, in which case you'd have to replace the entire waterline to fix the sagging pipe.

utterance.speaker: Fernando
utterance.content: I guess so. Hate to have your next-door neighbors end up with no hot water. Lucky the fire escaped your pipes entirely.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: It’s not working.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know. I started him back on the pain meds… Which means you can leave.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: My son was right. I tried for so long to protect him from… But I’m the one who's been selfish. This is no way for him to live.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Until we get an answer, it's the only way.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: There is no answer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There's always an answer.

utterance.speaker: Lynne
utterance.content: Then what is it? He’s been here four days. Three suicide attempts. You don't have an answer. When I saw you… When I saw the cane… I thought, "thank God. The doctor will understand." Because I sure as hell don't. My husband thinks it's over. So look me in the eye, tell me you'd want to live like that. Then stabilize him. Get him in decent enough shape for the drive home. So he can finally…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: There’s got to be something we can do. We can't just let the patient leave.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We didn't. House did.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Because he realized there's nothing he could do.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: There’s always something we can do, something else we can try.

utterance.speaker: Fernando
utterance.content: You’re insane. You know that, right?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because I have principles?

utterance.speaker: Fernando
utterance.content: Because you paid more to bribe me to lie on your claim than the entire cost of the repair.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don't care if I pay, as long as the people who pocketed my premiums for the last nine years also pay. I didn't break the pipe.

utterance.speaker: Fernando
utterance.content: Whatever. If you want to stick it to the man, that's fine by me. You happy?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope, but I’m right.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lock up on your way out. And don't touch the piano.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Testicles. What do they make you think of?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: STDs, testosterone issues, that summer on Fire Island.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Oh, so close. The correct answer is epilepsy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Epilepsy doesn't cause chronic pain.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It does if it spreads to the sensory region of the brain, then rewires the pain neurons.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Would’ve shown up on an EEG.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Not if the seizures are in a place you can't see on an EEG, a place too deep in the brain, like the area that controls the muscles supporting the…

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Testicles.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Feels like you got kicked in the nads, doesn't it? The abdominal pain, how it all started. It wasn't the stomach. It was lower, right?

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: It’s everywhere.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: But when it first started.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: It started in the stomach — cramps.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, like bad gas, or a permeating pain… Like your kidneys were being pulled out through your scrotum.

utterance.speaker: Jeff
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because epilepsy is treatable.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: Looks like we shot the guys with the torches.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Yeah. Pays to hang around.

utterance.speaker: Kutner
utterance.content: That selfish ass with the god complex who almost made the stupidest decision of his life — Wasn’t your colleague, was it? It was you.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No. See you tomorrow.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You’re here early.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: I’m feeling better. What's wrong?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: IV’s leaking a little. It’s no big deal. I’ll be right back.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Foreman. You busy tonight?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Rita, the spike on Dr. Hadley’s IV bag wasn't pushed in all the way. Don't want any dosing errors.

utterance.speaker: Rita
utterance.content: Sorry. It won't happen again. It stinks, doesn't it?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Rita
utterance.content: The medication. When we switch out the bags, you can smell it. It’s disgusting.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: I didn't smell anything.

utterance.speaker: Rita
utterance.content: Oh, she must be on the placebo, then.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You offered to do House's budget because you wanted him to owe you, wanted him to take that case. Why?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I thought it would help House. Seeing someone worse off than him, possibly curing a guy who has even less to look forward to.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Can I ask you something? How would you like my job?
